episode_title: How He Used Legacy Media to Build a $100M+ Business Empire with Craig Fuller
transcript:

So I'm going to list it out and you tell me where I'm wrong. Okay? So we've got Freight Waves, which is the largest shipping distributions logistics media company in the world. Then you've got Sonar, which is attached to it, which the way that I think about it is like Sonar is the Bloomberg terminal. Freight Waves is like Bloomberg Markets, the media arm of Bloomberg.


Craig Fuller (00:30.04)
You nailed it. You nailed it. Yeah, that's right.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:30.911)
Is it okay? Cool. I've listened to a couple of interviews and I've heard you talk about Bloomberg and I haven't heard you explicitly state that, but I'm like, seems like that's.

No, that is the exact interpretation.

Okay. And then you've got Firecrown, which are sort of an amalgamation of these, the way you call it, affluent enthusiast magazines or subscription media companies. Flying Magazine is one of them. Yachting Magazine is one of them. Model Trains, I don't know the exact name. Magazine is one of them. Did I miss anything in there?


Craig Fuller (01:02.884)
No, mean, it's really just happens to be transportation. Even Astronomy magazine, which has, you know, it's ultimately about, it's a science publication, but there is a transportation element, obviously rockets is a part of that. So it's really, it happens to be around transportation and it happens to be around affluent. Freight waves is obviously what I think the best way to sort of think of it is what Bloomberg does in the financial side of the economy.


between sonar, our data business, and between freight waves, our media business, we aspire to do in the physical goods economy. And that's how we think of

Can you give us just an idea of what's the revenue breakdown from each one of those company's employee counts?

Yeah, between all of the companies, over $100 million, if you looked at it in terms of employees, you're about 400 folks that are sort of full time. And then we have a number of contractors, particularly in the media side where we're paying someone to write a regular column and that's measured a couple hundred as well.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:06.945)
How do you look at it? Do you look at them all separately or is it like, okay.


Craig Fuller (02:11.182)
yeah, they're totally different businesses. In fact, there's different cap tables, there's different investors. So Sonar, the data business. So Freightways is really my first sort of business that I founded associated with media. And we found it hard to sell data. Venture backed businesses, know, media is not an attractive venture investment. And so anyone that's an aspiring media entrepreneur should not look at venture capital as the right way to go raise that capital.


But we found that if we wanted to create a data business that we had to both educate people with new data sets, but also evangelize it, we found that media was the right path to do that. Michael Bloomberg has written about that in Bloomberg, by Bloomberg, which is really the concept of using their own media business to drive top of funnel to the data business and the data terminal business. And it was the same way we built Sonar, which is our data business, but really was driven by Freightways Media. That was where I discovered media.


and then I had a knack for it and a love for it and a passion for it. And so I bought Flying Magazine, went and bought another, I think we own 50 different publications now. And then earlier, well, this is in 2024, I ended up buying the Freightways media business. So a totally separate cap tables, totally separate operations. Firecrown is our truly media business and Sonar is the data business.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:37.153)
Can you give an idea? All right, so if I'm going to break it up into three categories, fire, ground, fray wave, sonar, percentage basis of the 100 million in revenue where...

Mm-hmm.


the media business is far greater as a percent than Sonar. Yeah, because like in terms of valuation, if you were to evaluate those businesses, the data business is exponentially worth more on a multiple basis than media. Media trades at a multiple of EBITDA, subscription data businesses trade at a multiple of revenue. And so if you looked at it from a value standpoint, Sonar is the most valuable asset that I run.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:48.16)
It is.

but the predominance of revenues go through the media business.

Do you lump freight waves and Firecrown together as media?

Yeah, correct. So Freightways is now, Freightways Media, this is so confusing, because Freightways Media, which used to be a separate company, is now a part of Firecrown and Sonar is a separate business entirely. what happened is that, know, media businesses, only 25 % of it is sort of value-added to a consumer. In other words, if you think of media being the product, the content is the product, a very small portion of what it takes to run a media business is actually content production.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:31.956)
okay.

in the product itself, the predominance of is an infrastructure. It's ad cells, it's editorial that's non-value additive, it's layout if you're in magazines, it's audience development, it's all this stuff that frankly you and I as consumers of media could care less about, but if you run a successful media business, we have to have that infrastructure. And as we looked at the media business for FreightWaves, it made sense that you had all of these, all of this infrastructure.


on the fire crown side that we could then layer into freight waves and get more economies of scale. At the same time, the data business is far more valuable for investors.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:32.299)
So a lot of times we look at founders as like clairvoyant. man, they had a vision and they executed it and that's all they did. know, Henry Ford and Steve Jobs are the ilk of, hey, if were to ask the customers what they wanted, they would ask for a faster horse. You know what mean? Were you that way? Were you like, all right, I'm starting Freight Waves. We're to be a freaking media company. Or was this meandering process?


Craig Fuller (05:45.066)
Yeah.


Craig Fuller (05:52.566)
No. And I wonder how many of those, it's always like the victors write the history and you sort of look back in time, whether it's Steve Jobs, Elon Musk, know, some of the great founders, Henry Ford. And I would argue that again, I'm not, don't know their personal biographies, but I would argue that oftentimes in business, what you start out with as an idea and a concept is often not where you end


And I think what makes successful founders and entrepreneurs certainly been the case in my case, but I know many others, is that you're malleable and you are responsive to information. And you may have the same goal in mind, but how you get there and what the journey that it takes is quite different. So when I started FreightWaves, it never was a media company to begin with.


The goal is to bring transparency to freight markets. It's this big, huge industry that's quite opaque and nobody really knows what's going on. And our goal is to create a, idea was a futures market was the idea that we're gonna, futures markets is like wheat and oil and gold things and commodities. And you can trade those things and you sort of know what the real time pricing of those products are, but you also know what the future pricing is. And there's this whole information ecosystem that's around it.


That was the original idea, was to create more transparency and help companies understand what was happening in the market. We ended up launching futures contracts, but they weren't very successful in themselves. But out of that, we found that the market needed data and it needed information and news. And a friend of mine dropped off Michael Bloomberg's biography, Bloomberg by Bloomberg. And I read it and that was in many ways the playbook that I've adapted into Freight Waves.


And so that's how I got into media. You know, if you had asked me a decade ago, if I'd be a media executive, I would have thought you were nuts because again, writing, I was a lazy, lazy student and writing assignments. And I went to a school where we had never seen a multiple choice exam. it was an all boy boarding school in Tennessee. And, I had never seen a multiple choice exam until I got in college and you have these Scantrons that you would take.

Yeah.

Everything was writing and I hated and loathed writing. And now it's, you know, it's something I really am passionate about.


Nikolas Hulewsky (08:41.217)

Was that the idea with freight waves as you were like, hey, there's a lag for logistics in between whatever, shipping, sourcing, placing orders for different trucks or transportation vehicles.

Yeah, that's right. So it wasn't even data necessarily. It's like where the point of consumption happens in the goods. It's where the rubber really meets the road. It's like, if I'm at the gas station, that's the physical market. And that thing is open.


all the time and I can go buy fuel. There's this whole financial market that's in the background that really determines the price of both today's cost of goods, but also the future cost of goods, because there's all this arbitrage built into whether if commodities are likely to go up in the future, if we know if we have information, whether it's a storm perhaps that's hitting and knocking out the Gulf Coast and all of a sudden oil prices shoot up by 20 % or $10 or whatever it is, a barrel.


the price today will somewhat reflect that in the future, even though that event may not impact the physical market for months out. And so the idea in trucking is that this is massive fragmented market of hundreds of thousands of companies that are in it. There was no market to really understand and find price discovery. And so we set out to build that. And what we found is that building a futures market is a grand idea that's incredibly difficult to execute.


We were able to pull it off and actually launch futures contracts, but they never became liquid. But what we discovered along that journey is that what the market really wanted was better information. It wanted news and information and it wanted data. And that was ultimately the products we developed. So if go back to the original foundational idea, we ultimately executed what I said we were gonna do, which was bring transparency to the market. But the journey to get there, the products that we released, i.e. media,


were never, they never made the, in fact, when we raised our Siri seed round, which is in venture world, it's sort of like the, sort of the first round you raise, once you get into institutional, because you can raise money from friends and family, which is typically called an angel round. And the seed round is that first sort of like real institutional round. It's not a big, a lot of money, but it's sort of a validation from these institutional investors. Media never even made the pitch deck. In fact, my investors didn't even know.

is that he had imagined this was gonna be the fire festival because he didn't know that we could pull off an event. sort of fade away in the limelight are the ones that are able to, despite all the odds, sort of manifest something out of nothing. And that's what makes entrepreneurship magic in some ways, because you're able to really build something that just didn't exist before.

because the market has to sort of accept something they understand. so the most successful founders are not the ones creating these crazy, even Uber, which is the most successful startup in history in terms of revenue growth and speed of which it grew, was not an original idea. Hey, I, can I spend, can I pick your brain or I want to visit with you and I have an idea. And then you're like, fine, I'll spend 30 minutes just hashing out the idea knowing that it, that I'm not going to benefit directly from that. Like, like


It's good pay it forward. If I was a young founder, there were people who are gracious enough to spend time with me along that journey. But then they asked for an NDA, asked me to sign an NDA and I'm like, wait, why would I sign an NDA for you to share an idea that I'm going to spend the next 30 minutes giving you feedback on your idea that I don't personally benefit from. And yet you want me to sign something that restricts my rights. Makes no sense. So founders, it's offensive when you even ask it.


Because any time you're sharing an idea, whether an NDA has been signed or not, you have to assume that that idea, if it's good enough, has been A, heard before, and B, that the person you're sharing it with, you're not gonna teach them anything that they don't already know.


Nikolas Hulewsky (21:14.005)
Dude, I totally agree. The only time I'm really good about NDAs and I honestly, I only do this with people who I'm trying to show, hey, you're fine. We can trust each other. Craig Fuller (21:40.448)
No, what's the point? You had at that point, don't even, and oftentimes they won't even tell you what the idea is about. It's like, great. I want to hear about it. Like you have to sign it. different.

and said, screw it, I'll just do it myself.

And we went from signing up two banks in five years to over the course of a year and a half signing up 400. And I saw that the ABA, the American Bankers Association, when they put out a press release and sent it out via email, I think that day we had a couple of hundred come.


banks, community banks that responded, they wanted more information. And it was this aha moment for me because it was like the secret all along wasn't building better technology. The secret all along was distribution. And when I set up Start Freight Waves, regardless of what my product was, and when I started this business, we didn't have a product. things.

And so one of the things that I really did at Freight Waves was ensure that I got distribution. I just happened to do that through media.

because of the amount of social currency that that ends up creating.
